newsitem.title: HONG KONG: PRESS DIGEST - HK newspaper editorials - Jan 3.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - HK newspaper editorials - Jan 3.

text.p: These are some of the leading stories in the Hong Kong press on Thursday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
-- MING PAO -- Chief Executive-designate Tung Chee-hwa said he hoped some senior government officials could be seconded to his office before the handover.
-- As economic development slowed in recent years, the average monthly consumption of people in China's southern Guangdong province dropped to 550 yuan last year.
-- TA KUNG PAO -- Beijing criticised Taiwanese authorities for dismembering a provincial government, warning it was a dangerous move towards splitting the country.
-- Chinese President Jiang Zemin again urged the country to carry out the anti-corruption movement thoroughly and seriously.

-- SING TAO DAILY -- U.S. President Bill Clinton urged Beijing to give Hong Kong people a great deal of freedom after the handover, saying the territory might otherwise wind up being less useful to China.

-- ECONOMIC TIMES -- Giordano International's negotiations with its mainland Chinese partner over co-investment plans were suspended, and the group was talking to other Chinese companies about cooperation possibilities.

-- SOUTH CHINA MORNING POST -- The Securities and Futures Commission (SFC) approved Emperor International Exchange's application for a foreign exchange licence, but only after imposing a package of regulatory measures it described as "the most onerous in the history of the SFC".
-- China's new central depository had ambitious goals to clean up the chaotic state debt market and implement risk control to prevent losses from a chain of debts.
-- HONG KONG STANDARD -- John Greenwood, originator of the Hong Kong-U.S. dollar peg rate, said the Hong Kong dollar would benefit from a likely influx of yuan into the territory after the handover.
